To the chief Musician, <FI>A Psalm<Fi> of David the servant of the LORD. The transgression of the wicked saith within my heart, <FI>that there is<Fi> no fear of God before his eyes.
For he flattereth himself in his own eyes, until his iniquity be found to be hateful.<RF>until…: Heb. to find his iniquity to hate<Rf>
The words of his mouth <FI>are<Fi> iniquity and deceit: he hath left off to be wise, <FI>and<Fi> to do good.
He deviseth mischief upon his bed; he setteth himself in a way <FI>that is<Fi> not good; he abhorreth not evil.<RF>mischief: or, vanity<Rf><CM>
Thy mercy, O LORD, <FI>is<Fi> in the heavens; <FI>and<Fi> thy faithfulness <FI>reacheth<Fi> unto the clouds.
Thy righteousness <FI>is<Fi> like the great mountains; thy judgments <FI>are<Fi> a great deep: O LORD, thou preservest man and beast.<RF>the…: Heb. the mountains of God<Rf>
How excellent <FI>is<Fi> thy lovingkindness, O God! therefore the children of men put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.<RF>excellent: Heb. precious<Rf>
They shall be abundantly satisfied with the fatness of thy house; and thou shalt make them drink of the river of thy pleasures.<RF>abundantly…: Heb. watered<Rf>
For with thee <FI>is<Fi> the fountain of life: in thy light shall we see light.
O continue thy lovingkindness unto them that know thee; and thy righteousness to the upright in heart.<RF>continue: Heb. draw out at length<Rf>
Let not the foot of pride come against me, and let not the hand of the wicked remove me.
There are the workers of iniquity fallen: they are cast down, and shall not be able to rise.<CM>
